Or we can just note the direction of travel, which is undoubtedly negative to Shire's numbers.

11:18 am
BE

The sellside have been harassing their tax experts overnight, which helps put some meat on the first argument, Here's RBC, for example.

BE

The tax expert conference call this morning, hosted by noted expert Bob Willens, focused on the Treasury’s announcement last night. The SHPG/BXLT
transaction, while not the focus of the call, was discussed several times and we have provided a synopsis of the call and the discussion below.
BXLT likely to be treated as though it spun-off Baxter, additional BXLT shareholder stake in Shire would technically increase but ownership level
stays below 60%. Prior to the Treasury announcement and based on the current deal structure, Shire investors were to retain ~66% of the equity while Baxalta
shareholders would end up with ~34%. This is consistent with Shire commentary today that the deal was not an inversion. While the relative equity shares
would be unchanged from an economic perspective, Mr. Willens believes the new regulations appear to suggest that Shire would need to recognize Baxter as a
non-ordinary course distribution by Baxalta (a reverse spin), thereby significantly increasing the relative US equity contribution by Baxalta. In fact, the potential
necessity to include Baxter in the base equity value may have pushed the Baxalta (+Baxter) threshold over 60% creating a potential problem. This was new
information for us as we originally believed only minor earnings stripping might be involved in the deal. However, even under this cautious scenario Mr. Willens’
analysis suggested including Baxter in the equity base would still fall below the 60% threshold.

BE

Majority of debt is third-party, unlikely to affect earnings stripping. Mr. Willens agreed that Shire has not been recognized as a serial-acquirer in the past,
and acknowledged that it usually funds acquisitions using cash. This provides us with an additional level of comfort as SHPG has not grown by issuing equity to
fund its purchases of US companies. Additionally, we anticipate the majority of the debt to be third-party debt (both Dyax and Baxalta related debt) and
subsequently, do not anticipate the earnings stripping announcement to impact Shire. We note that the earnings stripping rules are not limited to inverted
companies; instead they will affect expanded groups that issue inter-company debt after April 4th, 2016 post a 90-day period once the regulations are published
in the Federal Register.
We are awaiting further comment from SHPG but do not believe that earnings stripping, or the inversion rules, will affect the BXLT acquisition.

11:19 am
PM

Bob Willens

BE

If you prefer, here's Dr. Reuven Avi-Yonah

BE

Who's Jefferies' tame tax expert.

11:20 am
BE

Professor of Law at the University of Michigan, no less.

PM

ok

BE

Expert Believes the “Serial Inverter” Rule is Essentially the “PFE Rule” and was
Designed Specifically to Derail the Proposed AGN Merger – Which He Now
Expects to Collapse: Regarding the first of the Treasury’s new regulations – which basically
reduces the effective size of a foreign acquisition target that had previously grown though a
series of US inversions – Dr. Avi-Yonah believes that this could be appropriately named the
“PFE rule” since in his view the regulation was drafted specifically to derail the co’s proposed
merger with AGN. He noted that the 3-year “lookback” – which just captures Actavis’ 2013
inversion with Warner-Chilcott – is the key element that shrinks AGN down to a size where
the full benefits of the proposed inversion cannot be realized. Specifically, PFE’s pro forma
ownership was originally expected to be 56% of NewCo, but with this new rule the co’s pro
forma ownership will likely fall somewhere between 70-80% and thus the 60/40 ownership
rule would certainly be violated. In Dr. Avi-Yonah’s view, PFE could take three courses of
action at this point: 1) continue with the merger while accepting the lower tax benefits, 2)
pursue litigation against the Treasury, or 3) walk away from the merger. The expert sees
little incentive for PFE to pursue the merger under these new terms. And while he thinks
litigation could actually be effective – particularly since the regulation is seemingly targeted
specifically at PFE and could be construed as discriminatory (e.g., Wal-Mart v Puerto Rico)
– this path would likely take “over a year” and there still wouldn’t be certainty that the co
would win. As such, our expert believes PFE will likely rescind its offer and scuttle the merger.

11:23 am
BE

You are. Here's some more from Dr Reuven.

BE

According to Dr. Avi-Yonah, Updated “Earnings Stripping” Regulations are
“Fuzzy” but Could Theoretically be Far-Reaching; He Believees These New Rules
Could Potentially Increase the Taxable Income to All Foreign Cos with US
Subsidiaries – If They’re Finalized: Our expert believes the second new category
of regulations related to “earnings stripping” was actually much broader and could be
more impactful to the wider industry (see details for more discussion on the mechanics of
earnings stripping). More specifically, Dr. Avi-Yonah noted that the rules are “fuzzy” since
it’s not exactly clear how the regulations have changed – i.e., general rules have been in
place since 1986 – but he noted that there’s a much clearer sense of enforcement now.
Most importantly, our expert believes that the new language regarding the ability to treat
intercompany debt as equity for accounting purposes will extend beyond just cos that have
previously completed inversions and thus theoretically could apply to any foreign co that
uses earnings stripping via a US subsidiary. Specific to previously inverted cos, Dr. Avi-Yonah
believes that most if not all cos that have previously completed an inversion very likely
utilize this mechanism and thus could face slightly higher future tax rates. We note that the
following Specialty Pharma cos have all inverted within the past several years and thus could
be impacted: AGN, ENDP, JAZZ, PRGO & VRX. All that said, our expert was quick to note
that these regulations have not yet been “finalized” and hence are effectively still considered
guidance. As such, it’s possible that they will 1) not be passed in their present form by the
current political leadership or 2) could fall to the next administration. In the latter case, our
expert believes that a Republican president would dismiss these regulations immediately
while even a new Democratic president could prove to be more “pro business.” All told,
there’s still a lot of moving parts and it’s unclear what impact, if any, these new rules will
have.

BE

So, yep, not even the legendary experts are sure.

BE

BE

We believe Medivation is unique; a profitable mid-cap and pure-play:
There are approximately nine profitable public U.S. biotech companies.
Medivation is the only one that is a mid-cap (~$7bn), and a pure-play.
In addition, Medivation has a cancer pipeline in two of the hottest areas
of oncology — immuno-oncology and genetically defined cancers (PARP
inhibitor). We believe the stock should command a scarcity value.

Scarcity remains a key part of the story. M&A is a common occurrence in
biotech, over the past 3 years 9 mid-cap peers have been acquired. While
we believe Medivation could become the next big biotech on its own, our
analysis would not be complete without laying out potential peer transactions to
establish an M&A valuation. Our analysis suggests $62 ($51-71 range)

11:29 am
BE

Medivation has been under the radar, but we believe the stock should
attract attention from generalist PM’s: The company is well run, and hits
numbers. Our analysis surprised us: MDVN is almost as stable as many largercap peers — as judged by experiencing only 2 "down 10%" days in 2 years
(see page 5). The stock looks attractive on a historical P/E, and historical P/S
basis, and looks appealing on a relative EV/S, and PE/G basis. We think the
stock is hard to ignore — in short, the company punches above its weight

11:47 am
BE

For a more sensible view, here's Tony.

BE

The story here is playing out in the way we have predicted for nearly two years. Having paddled very hard under the surface to maintain growth in the UK Directory, the feet have now fallen off and the question is will the duck stay afloat or should we be worried about more than just stagnation here?

From its own analysis Next now looks quite like M&S in the late-Rose period, facing a period of fundamental resetting of the business to get it fit-for-purpose. The question is how long it will take.

Our overwhelming reaction to the results is of surprise that management appeared to have relatively few solutions. Even the terms used to describe the travails of the UK Directory spoke to a business that has moved from being amenable to management inputs/levers to one more or less reactive to market conditions.

In a sense that is the issue here. There is plenty of opportunity to be exposed to beta in the General Retail sector but alpha is rare. Next has drifted out of the exclusive club. We have made modest reductions to profit forecasts which now assume full deployment of “surplus” cashflow to buy-backs. Our Fair Value is reduced by 2% from 6000p to 5900p reflecting Haitong eps forecast changes.

Having said this, the outcome is largely as we expected. We have made modest downgrades and the shares are down 30% price relative over four months and now stand on a comparable valuation to M&S. So long as the margin structure holds at Next we feel they offer decent value and have upgraded from Sell to BUY.

BE

We have now re-examined our more detailed modelling of the UK Directory in light of the disclosures accompanying these results. The rate of attrition of the credit customer base from -3% at the half year to -4.3% over the full year and
-5% forecast for the current year was the main new news to emerge. Clearly Next has been unable to stem the decline in its core customer base.

What prospect increased volatility?

The issue now in terms of whether Next’s overall financials are going to react in a less predictable way is whether there is downside gearing in the Directory P&L from loss of these customers. We have long argued that the main impact will be felt in the inability of the company to replenish its highest spending customers. This should develop progressively. But in the short term the numbers have also been benefiting from the low levels of recruitment of historically profit dilutive new credit customers. So the risk is some inflection point where the profit/customer mix within the Directory credit customer base moves adversely. Clearly there is insufficient disclosure to model this out currently. But we note that much of the investment made by Next over the past two years has been in functionality to improve retention rates. The debate is when the impacts of this will drop out.

Now better understood by investors

We believe that the new news here has now been discounted into the share price. Clearly there is scope for further newsflow to develop. But on the basis of what we have seen we are now much happier that investors understand the structural issues facing this company.

11:55 am
BE

Which is bottom of the range, but not a disaster.

BE

Here's BMO.

BE

Glencore has announced the sale of a 40% equity interest in its Agriculture Products business to the Canadian Pension Plan
Investment Board (CPPIB) for US$2.5B in cash. The transaction values the total Agriculture Products business at US$6.25B
and, with a long-term debt of ~US$0.6B, implies an EV of US$6.85B. Glencore’s Agriculture Products business includes
both the industrial and trading arms of the division, which reported a combined EBITDA of US$0.7B in 2015 and is forecast
to generate EBITDA of US$1.1B in 2016 on our estimates. Proceeds of the sale are to be used to pay down debt. Glencore
and CPPIB have agreed to a four-year lock-up period, with an option to sell a further 20% stake afterwards. Further,
Glencore and CPPIB may each call to IPO Glencore Agricultural Products after eight years from the close. The transaction
is subject to regulatory approval, but is expected to close in H2/16.
Our View:
 Mixed... A little light on valuation, but nevertheless still a positive step towards the debt reduction targets.
 On valuation…The agreed price of US$2.5B for 40% is below our estimated NPV10% of US$3.9B, split between
industrial (11%) and marketing (89%). On an EV/EBITDA basis, a 2016 implied EV/EBITDA multiple of ~6.4x is a
little light versus our estimated range of 7.0x-8.0x.
 But, it is yet another positive step towards achieving the debt reduction target. As a reminder, the company is targeting
reducing net debt (including adjustment for readily marketable inventories) to US$17-18B by end-2016 and US$15B by
end-2017 (US$25.9B in December 2015), in part from sales of US$4-5B for 2016 (excluding the streaming deals
already announced).
 On our current estimates, net debt is expected reduce to US$21B by end-2016 (net debt to EBITDA 2.5x) including
US$1.1B in sales this year; therefore the additional sales proceeds are a significant step towards reaching the 2016 yearend target. Negatively, we calculate the sale of 40% of the Agri business reduces free cash flow by ~US$0.3B to
~US$5.8B.

11:55 am
BE

And Canaccord.

BE

A reasonable price
We see this as a reasonable disposal price, though it is below book value and some
market expectations. The sale represents 50-62.5% of the US$4-5bn of additional
incremental proceeds from disposals targeted in the 2015 results. In addition, yesterday
the company's 70%-owned Kazzinc subsidiary announced the sale of the Komarovskoye
gold deposit in Kazakhstan to Polymetal for US$100M cash. Proceeds from both
disposals are expected to be used to reduce net debt.
What is Glencore Agri?
According to Glencore, the global business is "a differentiated and vertically-integrated
business focused on the global agricultural products value chain". It includes the
processing/production of sugar cane, wheat, rice, biodiesel,and various farming and
crushing activities, as well as over 200 storage facilities, 31 processing facilities and 23
ports. The trading business includes grains, oilseed products, rice, sugar, pulses and
cotton.
A further sale is possible
The agri business will have its own board, to include CPPIB representatives. Glencore
and CPPIB have agreed to a 4-year lock-up period subject to a carve-out for Glencore to
sell up to a further 20% of the agri business. Either party may call for an IPO for the agri
business after 8 years from the deal closing.
A good deal that de-risks Glencore
We see the disposal as a good deal for Glencore, putting the company well on the way
to meeting its disposal target, and lowers net debt, thereby de-risking the company. We
reiterate our speculative Buy recommendation and 180p target price.

BE

And Morgan Stanley, I guess.

11:57 am
BE

Net debt will be reduced by the equity portion of the transaction, being $2.5bn
(40% x $6.25bn). Glencore will still consolidate 100% of the business meaning
that transfer of RMI's, working capital and net debt will have no impact on the
consolidated net funding or net debt. This leaves net funding at $38.3bn
excluding 2016e FCF and Glencore definition net debt at $22.9bn excluding
2016e FCF. This also includes the $500m from the Antapaccay streaming deal.
Company targets for 2016e remain for net funding of $32-33bn, and net debt
of $17-18bn, leaving a gap to their targets of $5-6bn which will be filled by
further asset sales and FCF generation during 2016. Taking this into account
Glencore will be trading on a 2016e ND/EBITDA on spot of 2.6x if we include
our estimate of FCF generation in 2016e.
